text: Resolution adopted by the General Assembly on 30 December 2022
[on the report of the Fifth Committee (A/77/673, para. 10)]
77/267.	Shifting the management paradigm in the United Nations: review of changes to the budgetary cycle
The General Assembly,
Recalling its resolution 72/266 A of 24 December 2017,
textWithHighlights: *Recalling* its resolution 72/266 A of 24 December 2017,

text: Having considered the report of the Secretary-General entitled “Shifting the management paradigm in the United Nations: review of changes to the budgetary cycle” and the related report of the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions,

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions

textWithHighlights: *Having considered* the report of the {{Secretary-General}} entitled “Shifting the management paradigm in the {{United Nations}}: review of changes to the budgetary cycle” and the related report of the {{Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions}},
uncertainties: Classified the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions (ACABQ) as type 'other' since it is not explicitly listed among entities; it is a GA subsidiary body.

text: Takes note of the report of the Secretary-General;
textWithHighlights: *Takes note* of the report of the {{Secretary-General}};

text: Endorses the conclusions and recommendations contained in the report of the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions;

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions

textWithHighlights: *Endorses* the conclusions and recommendations contained in the report of the {{Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions}};
uncertainties: ACABQ is not in the provided entity list; treated as 'other' and normalized as ACABQ.

text: Recalls paragraphs 6 and 7 of its resolution 72/266 A, in which it approved the change from a biennial to an annual budget period on a trial basis, decides to lift the trial period effective from 2023, and requests the Secretary-General to continue with the submission of the programme budget according to an annual cycle;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Lift trial period for annual budget cycle
Programme budget submissions on annual cycle

textWithHighlights: *Recalls* paragraphs 6 and 7 of its resolution 72/266 A, in which it approved the change from a biennial to an annual budget period on a trial basis, *decides* to [[lift the trial period]] effective from 2023, and *requests* the <<Secretary-General>> to continue with the [[submission of the programme budget]] according to an annual cycle;
uncertainties: Classified “submission of the programme budget” as a report-type deliverable (document submission). Treated “lift the trial period” as a policy-type deliverable reflecting a decision on procedural policy.

text: Notes that the change from the biennial to the annual budget period on a trial basis was not cost-neutral, and also notes the lack of an activity-based costing system to account for the workload and associated costs of preparing programme budget documentation;
textWithHighlights: *Notes* that the change from the biennial to the annual budget period on a trial basis was not cost-neutral, and also *notes* the lack of an activity-based costing system to account for the workload and associated costs of preparing programme budget documentation;

text: Recalls paragraphs 19, 28 and 38 of the report of the Advisory Committee, and requests the Secretary-General to conduct a comprehensive review on the annual cycle, including its financial, administrative and procedural impact, its impact on the implementation of mandates across sections of the programme budget and the workload and the associated costs, and to submit a report for consideration by the General Assembly at the main part of its eighty-third session, in 2028;

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity_normalized: Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions (ACABQ)

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Comprehensive review on the annual cycle
Report for consideration by GA in 2028

textWithHighlights: *Recalls* paragraphs 19, 28 and 38 of the report of the {{Advisory Committee}}, and *requests* the <<Secretary-General>> to conduct a [[comprehensive review]] on the annual cycle, including its financial, administrative and procedural impact, its impact on the implementation of mandates across sections of the programme budget and the workload and the associated costs, and to submit a [[report]] for consideration by the {{General Assembly}} at the main part of its eighty-third session, in 2028;

text: Also recalls regulation 3.2, paragraphs 4 and 5, of the Regulations and Rules Governing Programme Planning, the Programme Aspects of the Budget, the Monitoring of Implementation and the Methods of Evaluation, reaffirms that the Fifth Committee is the appropriate Main Committee of the General Assembly entrusted with responsibilities for administrative and budgetary matters, and stresses the importance that the Fifth Committee make decisions on the programme budget in a timely manner;
textWithHighlights: Also *recalls* regulation 3.2, paragraphs 4 and 5, of the Regulations and Rules Governing Programme Planning, the Programme Aspects of the Budget, the Monitoring of Implementation and the Methods of Evaluation, *reaffirms* that the {{Fifth Committee}} is the appropriate Main Committee of the {{General Assembly}} entrusted with responsibilities for administrative and budgetary matters, and *stresses* the importance that the {{Fifth Committee}} make decisions on the programme budget in a timely manner;
uncertainties: "Fifth Committee" is not explicitly listed in the provided entity list; classified as a UN Organ and normalized as "Fifth Committee."

text: Reaffirms that no changes to the budget methodology, established budgetary procedures and practices or the financial regulations may be implemented without prior review and approval by the General Assembly in accordance with established budgetary procedures;
textWithHighlights: *Reaffirms* that no changes to the budget methodology, established budgetary procedures and practices or the financial regulations may be implemented without prior review and approval by the {{General Assembly}} in accordance with established budgetary procedures;

text: Recalls paragraph 11 of the report of the Advisory Committee, and requests the Secretary-General to present any proposed changes to the Financial Regulations and Rules of the United Nations and the Regulations and Rules Governing Programme Planning, the Programme Aspects of the Budget, the Monitoring of Implementation and the Methods of Evaluation for the consideration of the General Assembly;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: proposed changes to UN Financial Regulations and Rules and PPBME Regulations and Rules

textWithHighlights: *Recalls* paragraph 11 of the report of the {{Advisory Committee}}, and *requests* the <<Secretary-General>> to present any [[proposed changes]] to the Financial Regulations and Rules of the United Nations and the Regulations and Rules Governing Programme Planning, the Programme Aspects of the Budget, the Monitoring of Implementation and the Methods of Evaluation for the consideration of the {{General Assembly}};
uncertainties: "Advisory Committee" is assumed to refer to the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions (ACABQ). The deliverable is interpreted as the presentation of proposed policy changes to internal UN regulations and rules.

text: Also recalls its resolution 58/250 of 23 December 2003, reaffirms that there should be no exceptions to the rule that documents must be distributed in all official languages, emphasizes the principle that all official documents must be distributed simultaneously in all official languages before they are made available on United Nations websites, and reiterates its request to the Secretary-General to ensure that documents are available in accordance with the six-week rule for their distribution simultaneously in the six official languages;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Compliance with six-week rule
Simultaneous distribution in six official languages

textWithHighlights: Also *recalls* its resolution 58/250 of 23 December 2003, *reaffirms* that there should be no exceptions to the rule that documents must be distributed in all official languages, *emphasizes* the principle that all official documents must be distributed simultaneously in all official languages before they are made available on United Nations websites, and *reiterates* its request to the <<Secretary-General>> to ensure that documents are available in accordance with the [[six-week rule]] for their [[distribution simultaneously]] in the six official languages;
uncertainties: Classified compliance with the six-week rule and simultaneous distribution as standards; could arguably be framed as information_sharing/operational compliance.

text: Reaffirms that parts I and II of the proposed programme budget shall be submitted through the Committee for Programme and Coordination and part III through the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions for the consideration of the General Assembly;

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions

textWithHighlights: *Reaffirms* that parts I and II of the proposed programme budget shall be submitted through the {{Committee for Programme and Coordination}} and part III through the {{Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions}} for the consideration of the {{General Assembly}};

text: Also reaffirms the role of the Committee for Programme and Coordination as the main subsidiary organ of the General Assembly and the Economic and Social Council for planning, programming and coordination, as well as in verifying that the programmes of activities of the Organization are implemented in line with the legislative mandates and that the full implementation of regulations and rules is ensured;
textWithHighlights: Also *reaffirms* the role of the {{Committee for Programme and Coordination}} as the main subsidiary organ of the {{General Assembly}} and the {{Economic and Social Council}} for planning, programming and coordination, as well as in verifying that the programmes of activities of the {{Organization}} are implemented in line with the legislative mandates and that the full implementation of regulations and rules is ensured;
uncertainties: "Organization" is interpreted as the United Nations. The Committee for Programme and Coordination (CPC) is treated as a UN organ though it is not explicitly listed among predefined entities.

text: Recommends that the Committee for Programme and Coordination, in accordance with its mandate, provide recommendations on all programmes of the proposed programme budget;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Recommendations on all programmes of the proposed programme budget

textWithHighlights: *Recommends* that the <<Committee for Programme and Coordination>>, in accordance with its mandate, provide [[recommendations]] on all programmes of the proposed programme budget;
uncertainties: The Committee for Programme and Coordination (CPC) is not explicitly included in the provided entity list; classified as UN Organs and normalized with its common name/abbreviation.

text: Recalls that the Committee for Programme and Coordination shall consider the proposed programme plans in accordance with its terms of reference, and appreciates the continuous efforts of the Committee to reach consensus on all programmes of the proposed programme budget;
textWithHighlights: *Recalls* that the {{Committee for Programme and Coordination}} shall consider the proposed programme plans in accordance with its terms of reference, and *appreciates* the continuous efforts of the {{Committee}} to reach consensus on all programmes of the proposed programme budget;
uncertainties: CPC is not explicitly listed in the provided entity list; normalized here as "CPC" under UN Organs. No concrete deliverables or assignees present, as the paragraph reinforces roles and expresses appreciation.

text: Decides to extend the length of sessions of the Committee for Programme and Coordination to five weeks, starting from the sixty-third session of the Committee;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Extend CPC session length to five weeks

textWithHighlights: *Decides* to [[extend the length of sessions]] of the {{Committee for Programme and Coordination}} to five weeks, starting from the sixty-third session of the Committee;

text: Recalls paragraph 12 of its resolution 31/93 of 14 December 1976, and continues to encourage Member States to be represented at a high level of expertise and to ensure the continuity of their representation in the Committee for Programme and Coordination, whose central role and overall responsibilities are recognized;
textWithHighlights: *Recalls* paragraph 12 of its resolution 31/93 of 14 December 1976, and *continues to encourage* <<Member States>> to be represented at a high level of expertise and to ensure the continuity of their representation in the {{Committee for Programme and Coordination}}, whose central role and overall responsibilities are recognized;

text: Also recalls paragraph 22 of the report of the Advisory Committee, and reiterates that the Committee for Programme and Coordination and the Advisory Committee should examine the proposed programme budget in accordance with their respective mandates and, preserving the sequential nature of the review processes, submit their conclusions and recommendations to the General Assembly for the final approval of the programme budget;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: review proposed programme budget
submit recommendations to GA

textWithHighlights: Also *recalls* paragraph 22 of the report of the {{Advisory Committee}}, and *reiterates* that the <<Committee for Programme and Coordination>> and the <<Advisory Committee>> should [[examine]] the proposed programme budget in accordance with their respective mandates and, preserving the sequential nature of the review processes, submit their conclusions and [[recommendations]] to the {{General Assembly}} for the final approval of the programme budget;
uncertainties: "Advisory Committee" is assumed to refer to ACABQ (Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions), which is not explicitly expanded in the text.

text: Decides that the sessions of the Committee for Programme and Coordination shall end no later than mid-June to ensure more time for substantial deliberation of the programmes and consultation with relevant United Nations bodies, starting from the sixty-fourth session of the Committee, in 2024;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Session schedule policy (end by mid-June)
deliverables.deliverable: shall end no later than mid-June

textWithHighlights: *Decides* that the sessions of the {{Committee for Programme and Coordination}} [[shall end no later than mid-June]] to ensure more time for substantial deliberation of the programmes and consultation with relevant United Nations bodies, starting from the sixty-fourth session of the Committee, in 2024;
uncertainties: The deliverable could alternatively be categorized as 'meeting' (scheduling of sessions) rather than 'policy'; chose 'policy' as it sets an institutional rule.

text: Requests the Secretary-General to assess a procedure to inform the Advisory Committee of possible resource implications that may result from the recommendations of the Committee for Programme and Coordination, for the consideration of the General Assembly, to address the sequential nature of the review process under the annual cycle;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Assessment of procedure to inform Advisory Committee of resource implications

textWithHighlights: *Requests* the <<Secretary-General>> to [[assess a procedure]] to inform the {{Advisory Committee}} of possible resource implications that may result from the recommendations of the {{Committee for Programme and Coordination}}, for the consideration of the {{General Assembly}}, to address the sequential nature of the review process under the annual cycle;
uncertainties: "Advisory Committee" likely refers to ACABQ; not listed explicitly in the entity list, so normalized as "Other (Other United Nations Bodies)". The task "assess a procedure" could imply evaluating or proposing a procedure; categorized as analysis.

text: Re-emphasizes the role of the plenary and the Main Committees of the General Assembly in reviewing and taking action on the appropriate recommendations of the Committee for Programme and Coordination relevant to their work, in accordance with regulation 4.10 of the Regulations and Rules Governing Programme Planning, the Programme Aspects of the Budget, the Monitoring of Implementation and the Methods of Evaluation;
textWithHighlights: *Re-emphasizes* the role of the plenary and the Main Committees of the {{General Assembly}} in reviewing and taking action on the appropriate recommendations of the {{Committee for Programme and Coordination}} relevant to their work, in accordance with regulation 4.10 of the Regulations and Rules Governing Programme Planning, the Programme Aspects of the Budget, the Monitoring of Implementation and the Methods of Evaluation;
uncertainties: The operative verb appears as “re-emphasizes,” which is not explicitly listed; it is treated as a reinforcing verb and normalized to “emphasize.” The Committee for Programme and Coordination (CPC) is not in the provided entity list; it is treated as a UN Organ and normalized to the common abbreviation “CPC.” There are no explicit assignees or concrete deliverables in this paragraph.

text: Reiterates that whenever the Committee for Programme and Coordination cannot provide conclusions and recommendations on a given subprogramme or programme of the proposed programme budget, the plenary or the relevant Main Committee or Main Committees of the General Assembly responsible for those mandates will consider the said subprogramme or programme at the very start of its session in order to provide any conclusions and recommendations to the Fifth Committee, at the earliest opportunity, and no later than four weeks after the start of the session, for timely consideration by the Fifth Committee;

assignees.assignee: relevant Main Committee or Main Committees of the General Assembly

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Review subprogramme or programme
Provide conclusions and recommendations to Fifth Committee

textWithHighlights: *Reiterates* that whenever the {{Committee for Programme and Coordination}} cannot provide conclusions and recommendations on a given subprogramme or programme of the proposed programme budget, the <<plenary>> or the <<relevant Main Committee or Main Committees of the General Assembly>> responsible for those mandates will [[consider]] the said subprogramme or programme at the very start of its session in order to provide any [[conclusions and recommendations]] to the {{Fifth Committee}}, at the earliest opportunity, and no later than four weeks after the start of the session, for timely consideration by the {{Fifth Committee}};
uncertainties: Assignees are inferred from the clause 'will consider' within a paragraph headed by a reinforcing verb ('Reiterates'); this reads as a procedural expectation rather than a direct request. Normalization of 'relevant Main Committee(s) of the GA' to 'GA Main Committees' is not in the predefined list and is introduced as a concrete UN Organs entity. The deliverable 'consider' is treated as a 'review' action, and 'conclusions and recommendations' as 'recommendations' directed to the Fifth Committee.

text: Decides that the Fifth Committee will consider the report of the Committee for Programme and Coordination at the earliest opportunity during the main part of the sessions of the General Assembly, under the agenda item entitled “Programme planning”, and no later than the first week of November;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Consideration of CPC report

textWithHighlights: *Decides* that the <<Fifth Committee>> will [[consider the report]] of the {{Committee for Programme and Coordination}} at the earliest opportunity during the main part of the sessions of the {{General Assembly}}, under the agenda item entitled “Programme planning”, and no later than the first week of November;

text: Recognizes the efforts of the President of the General Assembly and the Chair of the Fifth Committee in following up with the Chairs of the relevant Main Committees on the consideration of the programmes without recommendations from the Committee for Programme and Coordination, in accordance with paragraph 16 of its resolution 76/236 of 24 December 2021, and decides that incoming Presidents of the General Assembly and Chairs of the Fifth Committee shall reach out to and support the Chairs of the Main Committees to ensure that conclusions and recommendations are issued on time;

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: Chairs of the relevant Main Committees

assignees.assignee: incoming Presidents of the General Assembly

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: conclusions and recommendations issued on time

The deliverable focuses on the outcome (conclusions and recommendations issued on time) rather than the process actions (“reach out”/“support”), which are not mapped to a deliverable category.

text: Requests the Secretary-General to ensure that all the Main Committees have access on their Committee Places of the e-deleGATE portal, for information purposes, before the start of the session, to the programmes of the proposed programme budget and the latest report of the Committee for Programme and Coordination;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Access to programmes of the proposed programme budget and latest CPC report via e-deleGATE

textWithHighlights: *Requests* the <<Secretary-General>> to ensure that all the {{Main Committees}} have [[access]] on their Committee Places of the e-deleGATE portal, for information purposes, before the start of the session, to the programmes of the proposed programme budget and the latest report of the {{Committee for Programme and Coordination}};
uncertainties: Classified the deliverable as information_sharing (ensuring access to documents via a portal). "Main Committees" and "Committee for Programme and Coordination" are treated as UN Organs though not explicitly listed in the provided entity list.

text: Decides to extend the length of the first resumed session of the Fifth Committee to five weeks, starting from its seventy-eighth session;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Extend length of Fifth Committee first resumed session to five weeks

textWithHighlights: *Decides* to [[extend the length]] of the first resumed session of the {{Fifth Committee}} to five weeks, starting from its seventy-eighth session;
uncertainties: Classified the deliverable under 'meeting' since it changes the duration of a specific session rather than creating a new policy instrument.

text: Notes the increased workload on the Fifth Committee, the Committee for Programme and Coordination, the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions and the Secretariat;

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions

textWithHighlights: *Notes* the increased workload on the {{Fifth Committee}}, the {{Committee for Programme and Coordination}}, the {{Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions}} and the {{Secretariat}};

text: Reiterates its request to the Secretary-General to ensure that results and, where possible, performance measures actually reflect achievements and impacts in the implementation of the programmes of the Organization and not those of individual Member States;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Ensure results and performance measures reflect achievements and impacts

textWithHighlights: *Reiterates* its request to the <<Secretary-General>> to [[ensure]] that results and, where possible, performance measures actually reflect achievements and impacts in the implementation of the programmes of the {{Organization}} and not those of individual {{Member States}};
uncertainties: Deliverable type could be interpreted as policy rather than standards; chose standards because it concerns measurement norms.

text: Recalls paragraphs 33 and 46 of the report of the Advisory Committee, stresses that accountability is a central principle of management reform, and requests the Secretary-General to continue his efforts to ensure a strong culture of responsibility and accountability, compliance with regulations and rules, and the achievement of results;

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity_normalized: Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions

textWithHighlights: *Recalls* paragraphs 33 and 46 of the report of the {{Advisory Committee}}, *stresses* that accountability is a central principle of management reform, and *requests* the <<Secretary-General>> to continue his efforts to ensure a strong culture of responsibility and accountability, compliance with regulations and rules, and the achievement of results;
uncertainties: "Advisory Committee" is interpreted as the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions (ACABQ). No concrete deliverable extracted from the request as the tasks are broad (continue efforts, ensure culture/compliance/results).

text: Expresses its support for the efforts of the Secretariat to better engage and support programme managers with the aim of making the Organization more effective and results-oriented, and welcomes the commitment and ongoing efforts of the Secretariat to improve and update the programmatic aspects, including planned results, performance measures and external factors, of the programme budget;
textWithHighlights: *Expresses its support* for the efforts of the {{Secretariat}} to better engage and support programme managers with the aim of making the Organization more effective and results-oriented, and *welcomes* the commitment and ongoing efforts of the {{Secretariat}} to improve and update the programmatic aspects, including planned results, performance measures and external factors, of the programme budget;

text: Stresses that effective and efficient mandate delivery is the overriding factor in determining the Secretariat’s resource requirements;
textWithHighlights: *Stresses* that effective and efficient mandate delivery is the overriding factor in determining the {{Secretariat}}’s resource requirements;

text: Requests the Secretary-General to ensure effective and efficient utilization of available resources and programme delivery by programme managers, including through clearly defined results-based performance indicators and benchmarks;

text: Notes with appreciation the cumulative improvements to the presentation format of the proposed programme budget resulting from the implementation of the guidance from the General Assembly during the annual budget trial period, and welcomes the submission of the proposed programme plan and programme performance alongside the proposed post and non-post resource requirements in a single document;
textWithHighlights: *Notes with appreciation* the cumulative improvements to the presentation format of the proposed programme budget resulting from the implementation of the guidance from the {{General Assembly}} during the annual budget trial period, and *welcomes* the submission of the proposed programme plan and programme performance alongside the proposed post and non-post resource requirements in a single document;
uncertainties: No assignees or deliverables are explicitly designated. The paragraph acknowledges past actions (e.g., submission), so these are not marked as deliverables.

text: Recalls paragraph 45 of the report of the Advisory Committee, reaffirms the programmatic nature of the United Nations budget, and requests the Secretary-General to preserve the optimal functioning of all programmes by improving the presentation of and the link between proposed resources and programme delivery.

improve link between resources and programme delivery
